div1.p: Carter discusses his new post and family news.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, January 23, 1887
div1.opener:
C1
B22
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798
U.S.
1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of New Orleans La, Surgeon's Office,
Jan 23, 1887.
Dear Ma;
div1.p:
I haven't written to you for nearly a month.
Nevertheless we are all moderately well here, Laura is I think
very well- hasn't been so all the time but has not been sick & is cer-
tainly well now. I was a little sick yesterday & have been
under the weather all winter feel better today than I have for some-
time. Things are better than last year, but this is the
most aggravating post I have ever had in every respect
save climate. I believe the climate suits me.

We rather hope that the winter is over. There has been
a great deal more cold weather than last winter
but none so cold as the cold spell. There has been a
freeze about 2 days in a fortnight-slight freeze. The
wind here during a blizzard is horrible. I never saw such
a wind save for 2 days in S. F.

We have had an uncommonly dry winter - today is the
first hard rain I've since sin summer & I think
about 8 inches must have fallen. Taken altogether a
better climatic winter than last one.

I think Mary is about well- her throat is not but
not bad, but her dyspepsia seems, to be all right
She is in much better spirits than when in San Francisco,
indeed something like other girls- save more unselfish
Our cow has gone dry for about a month- hence we will
have a milk bill until some time in April. I think
I think we will have things green here in about 2 weeks
It has been so dry & there has been so much dry grass that I have been
afraid of fire

I had a letter from Jno Dox yesterday; He seems to be doing
moderately well. I was favorably impressed with him when I saw
him & he writes with less reserve than he used to. I will send him
the journals that I take. I am not filing them & they ought to do
him a great deal of good.

I have not written to Ned since he went abroad,
have been feeling to mean to do so, If I continue as
I promise today I will write this week,

We had one case of Lock Jaw last week - negro is under Dr. Pelters care - who
died. They generally do of Lock Jaw not of D. P.) we have some very sick patients, but not
many- not so many as last year. I am now changing the
hot water system of the wards & have authority to get bids for the
repair of the Steward's house. I hope that that is all of the work
which the I will be allowed to do this spring. The children
are a great deal stronger Put out trees than last year. Eat well & sleep well.
How is everything at North River I wish you would write me of all the
farming & everything else there.
Give my love to all there atHills.

This is nearly as late as you can send rose slips.
I have just written to Ned
